citation.article-title: Amphibacillus xylanus gen. nov., sp. nov., a facultatively anaerobic sporeforming xylan-digesting bacterium which lacks cytochrome, quinone, and catalase.

p.s: Description of Amphibacillus xylanus sp. nov.
Amphibacillus xylanus (xy. la' nus. M. L. adj. xylanus, xylan)
The species has all of the characteristics that define the genus.
In addition, it has the characteristics described below.
Cells are motile by means of flagella or nonmotile.
In aerobic and anaerobic cultures, colonies on glucose agar are small, circular, smooth, convex, entire, and white after 1 day of incubation.
Nitrate reduction, H2S production, indole production, citrate utilization, and hydrolysis of gelatin are negative.
Utilizes D-xylose, L-arabinose, D-ribose, D-glucose, D-fructose, esculin, salicin, maltose, sucrose, cellobiose, trehalose, soluble starch, pectin, and xylan (oat spelt).
Grows at temperatures between 25 and 45°C but not at 50°C and grows in the presence of 3% NaCl but not in the presence of 6% NaCl.
The fermentation product from xylan in aerobic cultures is acetic acid, and the fermentation products in anaerobic cultures are formic acid, ethanol, and acetic acid.
Variable characteristics for the species are shown in Table 6.
Cells of strain SinIV are weakly gram positive.
Strains have been isolated from composts of manure with grass and rice straw.
The type strain is strain Ep01.
This strain is nonmotile, and its DNA base composition is 36 mol% G+C.
It was isolated from an alkaline compost of manure with grass and rice straw (10).
The type strain has been deposited in the Japan Collection of Microorganisms, RIKEN, Wako-shi, Saitama, Japan, as strain JCM 7361.
